Award.AwardTitle: Third University of Florida SIAM Gators Conference, March 27-29, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
Third University of Florida SIAM Gators Conference, March 27-29, 2014

A three day student conference will be hosted by the student chapter of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) in the Mathematics Department of the University of Florida. The conference will be organized by students with faculty acting as advisors. There will be 6 keynote talks given by invited professors, while 21 talks will be given by students. The conference will have 3 focus areas: numerical optimization and applications, mathematical modeling and algorithms in imaging, and mathematical biology and modeling. The conference will showcase the latest computational techniques in the fields of optimization and imaging, as well as state-of-the art models in biomathematics. Students will have the opportunity to meet experts in their own and related fields, and will be able to network with other students in the focus areas of the conference. The student organizers of the conference will develop organizational skills, and skills in interacting and communicating with other researchers.

The conference will help students from the three interrelated fields of numerical optimization, imaging sciences, and mathematical biology achieve a broader view of their research and their field as they learn from and interact with researchers who work in application fields such as medical imaging technology and disease modeling and treatment. The conference will plant the seeds for future research projects. By networking with other students, a foundation for future collaborations will be established. The abstracts of the presented papers will be publicly available on the conference web site.

Conference web site: siam.math.ufl.edu/conference/

POR.DRECONTENT:
A three day student conference was hosted by the student chapter of the
Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) in the
Mathematics Department of the University of Florida.
The conference was organized by students with faculty acting as advisors.
The three focus areas in the conference were numerical optimization and
applications, mathematical modeling and algorithms in imaging, and
mathematical biology and modeling. There were three external keynote
speakers: Suzanne Lenhart from the University of Tennessee
(mathematical biology), Watao Yin from UCLA (imaging), and Samuel Burer
from the University of Iowa (optimization). In addition, there were
three keynote talks given by University of Florida faculty:
Juliet Pulliam (modeling of diseases), Thomas Mareci (modeling the
brain with magnetic resonance imaging), and Panos Pardalos (optimization
heuristics for mining large data sets). Altogether, there were 24 talks by
student particpants in the three conference focus areas.

The conference showcased the latest computational techniques in the fields of
optimization and imaging, as well as state-of-the art models in
biomathematics. Students had the opportunity to meet experts in their own
and related fields, and were able to network with other students in the
focus areas of the conference. The student organizers of the conference
developed organizational skills, and skills in interacting and
communicating with other researchers.

The conference helped students achieve a broader view of their research
and their field by learning about application areas and work in related areas.
The conference planted seeds for future research projects and collaborations.
A web page was developed for the conference at

       http://siam.math.ufl.edu/conference/

The conference program can be downloaded at

       http://siam.math.ufl.edu/files/SIAM-Gator-Conf_program.pdf


Last Modified: 03/05/2016
Modified by: William W Hager

In addition, there were three keynote talks given by University of Florida faculty: Juliet Pulliam (modeling of diseases), Thomas Mareci (modeling the brain with magnetic resonance imaging), and Panos Pardalos (optimization heuristics for mining large data sets). Students had the opportunity to meet experts in their own and related fields, and were able to network with other students in the focus areas of the conference.
